citations.desc: ATTENDING VETERINARIAN AND ADEQUATE VETERINARY CARE (DEALERS AND EXHIBITORS).
citations.narrative:
2.40 (a) (1) There was no written Program of Veterinary Care (PVC) available at the time of inspection. In order to
ensure problems of animal health are addressed adequately, there needs to be a written PVC. The written PVC
shall include the species being utilized or sold in regulated activities, preventative care, common health problems
they may have and how these will be addressed by the licensee and the Attending Veterinarian.
Ensure that the formal arrangement with the Attending Veterinarian includes a detailed written Program of
Veterinary Care and is made available for review during the inspection process.
To be corrected by: April 4, 2016

During the inspection there was no records of acquisition (Record of Animals on Hand) available which fully and
correctly disclosed the required information for all the animals being utilized in regulated activities. Maintaining
current records of animals on hand, including acquired and disposed of, is required in order to be able to accurately
track the animals.
Make, keep and maintain records which fully and correctly disclosed the required information regarding acquisition
and disposition of all the animals. Ensure that all records of acquisitions and dispositions are available for review
during the inspection process.
To be corrected by: April 4, 2016
.

3.129 (a) Inside the enclosure housing 5 sheep hay is being fed directly on the ground. The feeder was observed
lying on the ground with the stand no longer attached. There was fecal material lying on top of the hay and the
animals had to walk on the hay to get to the water trough. Feeding on the ground where food becomes
contaminated with fecal material increases the risk of infection with intestinal parasites.
Provide food that is wholesome, palatable and free from contamination.
To be corrected by: April 1, 2016
Inspection and exit briefing were conducted with a facility representative.
